There is a lot to be said for keeping fabric flowers in vases! And check out the book "Deadly Daffodils Toxic Caterpillars" by Christopher Holstege, M.D. and Carol Ann Turkington. It's aimed towards families, but anyone could need the information inside. It's quite surprising what foods, plants, chemicals, insects, etc., can be harmful to us and our pets.

I love SciShow, so I don't want to be critical, but here goes: Olivia has a fantastic speaking voice, when given a chance. But this video, in particular, seems to have been edited in an especially 'jump-cutty' way, cutting the pauses in her speaking in an annoyingly harsh way. Back in the day when videos needed to be shorter, doing this may have made sense, but why do it so harshly now? I honestly think that if this video had been even ten seconds longer, by making the cuts a little less deep, it would have been so much more cohesive and coherent.

Some folks have said things like, 'Oh, kids these days are used to this,' and I have three things to say to that: 1. Really? Show me evidence of that (this is a science channel, after all.) 2. Even if they are used to it, that doesn't mean that they are able to comfortably process the information that is so quickly and brokenly presented. My very bright teen-aged son finds it so jarring that he stopped watching these. 3. Not everyone who watches SciShow (and other videos that do this) are kids. I turn 60 this year.

SciShow. You've omitted a major downside to daffodils; cultivated daffodils are loaded with many different host generalist plant viruses. This is because winged female aphids flying about to establish new colonies in the spring and summer routinely replenish their sugar supply by feeding from daffodils. If they are carrying viruses in their stylets they will infect the daffodils with these, and also will pick up any viruses that they are not already carrying which the daffodils are carrying. It only takes a very brief feeding session for aphids to transmit/acquire plant viruses.

The role of aphids and daffodils as transmitter/reservoir of plant viruses was not widely recognized by plant virologists until the 1930s, because daffodils are too toxic for most aphids to colonize. Instead, winged female aphids feed briefly, then leave in search of more suitable host plants.

The flowers of many daffodils are very attractive to some species of thrips (as are many other white and/or yellow flowers, such as Dandelions and White Hybrid Tea Roses). Several species of thrips are both hosts and vectors of Tomato Spotted Wilt Virus, which actually replicates in both thrips and plants, and which can infect a huge range of plant hosts, including daffodils, citrus, camellias, orchids, impatiens, Tomatoes, grasses, and ferns.

There's poison hemlock growing a couple of meters from my flat.. Warned the municipality but they kind of only made it worse I think. Will see soon come spring.
You'd think the most poisonous plant on this continent (Europe) in the middle of a residential area deserves attention but they seem more worried about Giant hogweed, which is nasty but not by far as good at killing people and animals. PH can even kill just through air if jostled and damaged enough, say like by unaware workers tending city greens.
It's also very easy to miss the connection with coming into contact with any kind of plant, there's a delay of several hours between exposure and problems starting, it kills by stopping breathing eventually if the dose was sufficient.

Oh well, warned them, made a fuss. Not going to try to remove it myself, the poison in question diffuses through most consumer level household gloves and "doctor's" type gloves you can get at stores and as said can spread through air when the plant's damaged.
They ran over it twice with a special vacuuming mower, but that doesn't remove root systems and well, poison hemlock is a tough weed, it can survive underground and sprout in spring again same as some of the herbs I grow like mint. Wonder if it'd die with some daffodils around, at least more people seem to be aware of certain common toxic flowers :')
